awd_titl_txt: Miniaturized Reconfigurable Wearable Antenna for Dynamic On-Body Wireless Communication
awd_abstract_narration:
The emerging technology of wireless body-area networks promises to transform health care for millions of people whose daily lives are severely restricted by chronic conditions such as heart disease, stroke, cancer, and diabetes.  Advances in miniature sensors and wireless communications have opened the possibility for wearable, on-body sensors that remotely and continuously monitor physiological vital signs and transmit alerts to medical caregivers who can intervene in case of impending emergencies.  A major hurdle is that the sensors' antennas require relatively large amounts of electrical power to reliably transmit data over extended periods of time during regular daily life.  More efficient, optimized antenna designs are needed so that sensor batteries can be small and long-lasting, thereby allowing sensors to be convenient and unobtrusive.  To facilitate efficient on-body antenna designs, this project combines experimental and computer modeling methods to study and characterize how electromagnetic waves transmit over and around the moving human body.  Insights from analysis of measurement and simulation data guide the design of reconfigurable, wearable antennas that facilitate efficient, on-body wireless communication for continuous, remote health monitoring. 

The aim of this project is to study on-body electromagnetic wave propagations during human daily activities in order to guide the design of 3-D printed, reconfigurable, wearable antennas for unobtrusive, power-efficient, on-body wireless communications. Both measurement and simulation approaches are utilized in this project: i) three-dimensional body motions and complex electromagnetic transmission characteristics are simultaneously measured during common human activities for various on-body antenna configurations and in various environments; and ii) a three-dimensional modeling framework that reproduces experimental results and predicts wave transmission characteristics is established in electromagnetic simulation software. One key intellectual merit of this approach is relating on-body electromagnetic characteristics to body postures and antenna kinematics. Another key intellectual merit of the proposed work is designing and creating 3-D printed, electrically-small, reconfigurable, wearable antennas that couple radiation power into the dominant propagation mechanism. These advances will transform life-saving on-body communication technologies with applications that benefit patients, public safety officers, soldiers, and astronauts.

por.por_cntn:
The major outcome of this research project is a novel experimental platform which combines vector network analyzer, motion capture system, and full wave electromagnetic simulation software. The established platform can simultaneously measure and simulate three-dimensional human body motions and complex electromagnetic transmission characteristics during common human activities. Based on the experimental platform, measurements and simulations were performed across different human subjects, antenna types, daily activities, and antenna placements. It is found that the dominant on-body wireless propagation mechanism is a surface wave for line-of-sight cases and a creeping wave for non-line-of-sight scenarios. The propagation speeds and attenuation rates of both surface wave and creeping wave are identified.

A human body phantom model with arm swinging capability has also been developed in this project to provide a controlled environment for on-body wireless channel study. The phantom model is modular in design and filled with liquid mixture equivalent to human muscle tissue. The phantom model measurement was compared with measurement from multiple human volunteers and showed similar pattern, periodicity, and transmission magnitudes. It is also found the arm swinging speed affects on-body wireless propagation due to the Doppler effects.

Different types of wearable antennas (monopoles, microstrip antennas, 3-D printed cylindrically folded helix, and electronic textile dipoles) have been designed at ISM frequency bands and tested on both the human phantom model and real human subjects. It is found that the monopole is the best antenna candidate for on-body transmission when the human is doing movements. A durability study of the e-textile antennas was also performed, and it was found washing can detune the antenna resonance and pilling is detrimental to wearable e-textile antenna performance.

Our study also indicates that field interactions between an on-body antenna and a dynamic moving human body contain rich information of motion characteristics and can be harnessed for human activity recognition purposes.  It was found that the on-body antenna transmission and reflection coefficients exhibited unique time-varying periodic patterns for different activities. By utilizing just two on-body antennas, we were able to classify both large-scale and small-scale body motions with over 90% classification accuracy, which is higher than the accuracy of a two-accelerometer wearable system. This higher accuracy is achieved since both reflection coefficients of each individual antenna and transmission coefficient between antennas can be combined for classification purposes.  

The above research outcomes of this project have resulted in twelve leading journal article publications, fourteen premier conference presentations, three best student poster awards, and two U.S. patent applications (one granted in Mar. 2020, and the other pending). The project has also supported five Ph.D. graduates including two minority students and one female student. The REU supplement of this research project has supported ten undergraduate students, many of whom female and minority. The INTERN supplement of this research project has supported one Hispanic graduate student to work on using indoor wireless signals to locate and track human subjects in real time at a local technology start-up company.

Besides the above journal publications and conference presentations, the research findings have also been shared and demonstrated at a local WACO ISD high school to inspire students into pursuing the STEM field of studies. The PIs have also reached out to physicians and physical therapists at Waco to promote using wearable antenna system to track human motions and establish long-term collaborative relationships.
